tool.name: SnpEff build:
tool.command:
#if str( $fasta.fasta_selector ) == "yes": python3 '$__tool_directory__/gbk2fa.py' '${input_gbk}' '${output_fasta}' #if $fasta.remove_version: '${fasta.remove_version}' #end if && #end if
mkdir '${snpeff_output.files_path}' &&
mkdir '${snpeff_output.files_path}'/'${genome_version}' &&
ln -s '${input_gbk}' '${snpeff_output.files_path}'/'${genome_version}'/genes.gbk &&
snpEff -Xmx8g build -v -configOption '${genome_version}'.genome='${genome_version}' -configOption '${genome_version}'.codonTable='${codon_table}' -genbank -dataDir '$snpeff_output.files_path' '$genome_version'

param.name: genome_version
param.label: Name for the database
param.help: for E. coli K12 you may want to use 'EcK12' etc.

validator.message: A genome version name is required

param.name: input_gbk
param.label: Genbank dataset to build database from
param.help: This Genbank file will be used to generate snpEff database

param.name: codon_table
param.label: Select genetic code for this sequence
param.help: If this sequence uses non-standard genetic code, select one from these options

param.name: fasta_selector
param.label: Parse Genbank into Fasta
param.help: This will generate an additional dataset containing all sequences from Genbank file in FASTA format

param.name: remove_version
param.label: Remove sequence version label?
param.help: Genbank sequences have vesion numbers such as B000564.2. This option removes them leaving only B000564

tool.help:
**What it does**
This tool uses `"snpEff build -genbank"` command to create a snpEff database from a Genbank dataset. If **Parse Genbank into Fasta** is selected (the default behavior) the tool will also convert Genbank dataset into a single FASTA dataset.
Using Genbank data for creating databases has several advantages:
#. Genbank files contains annotations (such as locations of genes) together with sequences. This was one ensures that these two are in sync with each other #. When you are analyzing small genomes it is much more convenient to create a database on the fly and use it.
-------
.. class:: infomark
**The usage scenario**
Suppose you have a series of Illumina reads from an experiment involving *E. coli* K-12 MG1655. You want to map these reads to the reference genome of K-12 MG1655, call variants, and annotate them using snpEff. This tool enables you to follow the following analysis steps:
#. Download genome from `NCBI <ftp://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genomes/all/GCF/002/966/145/GCF_002966145.1_ASM296614v1/GCF_002966145.1_ASM296614v1_genomic.gbff.gz>`_ into Galaxy. #. Use **Genbank2Fasta** converter to generate FASTA dataset containing the genome #. Use your Illumina reads to map against this FASTA dataset using BWA-MEM #. Call variants using **Freebayes** #. Use this tool to generate a snpEff database from the file you downloaded at step 1. #. Annotate vcf output of Freebayes using snpEff tool (using *Custom* option for **Genome source** parameter)
In this scenario Genbank dataset is used twice. First, it is used to produce FASTA sequences that are using by BWA to map against. Second, it is used to create snpEff database. This guarantees that you will not have any issues related to reference sequence naming.
@EXTERNAL_DOCUMENTATION@
